Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Analysis and processing of multidimensional data using sparse directional multiscale representations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Labate, DMS-1008900
Guo, DMS-1008907

Following the spectacular success of wavelets in signal and
image processing, several attempts have been made to adapt their
optimal efficiency from the one- to the multi-dimensional
setting. In fact, in spite of their remarkable properties,
wavelets are not very efficient in capturing the intrinsic
geometry of multidimensional phenomena. In recent years,
directional multiscale methods such as the shearlet
representation, introduced by the investigators and their
collaborators, have emerged as the most effective extension of
the wavelet framework to the multidimensional setting. Indeed,
the shearlet representation encompasses the mathematical theory
of affine systems and, to date, is the only method able to
combine optimal sparsity and fast transforms through the power of
multiresolution analysis. The proposed research focuses on
applications of the shearlet approach to a number of challenging
problems of analysis and processing of multidimensional data.
First, the shearlet representation is applied to provide a
precise geometric characterization of the discontinuities of
multivariate functions and distributions. Combining techniques
from harmonic analysis and differential geometry, this provides
the groundwork for the development of improved algorithms for
edge detection and feature extraction. Second, the shearlet
framework is applied to develop a new generation of methods for
the regularized inversion of ill-posed problems. Building on the
ability of shearlets to provide sparse representations of Fourier
integral operators, efficient decompositions for the Radon and
Ray transforms are computed. These are used to develop
algorithms for the Radon inversion from local and incomplete data
and for image deconvolution. Third, a novel mathematical and
computational approach for viewpoint-invariant texture retrieval
is introduced. This is achieved by jointly designing a framework
for feature extraction and similarity measurement in an
appropriate statistical setting, and relies on the unique ability
of shearlets to capture local geometric information.

Over the past several years, there has been a continuously
increasing pressure to handle more efficiently the ever larger
and higher dimensional data sets generated from a wide range
applications such as electronic surveillance, remote sensing, and
medical imaging. The challenge is to rapidly, accurately and
reliably extract the relevant information, so that it can be
efficiently processed, transmitted and stored. The project
focuses on the applications of the shearlet representation -- a
method introduced by the investigators and their collaborators
that provides a unique combination of optimal sparsity and
computational efficiency, within an innovative mathematical and
computational framework. The notion of optimal sparsity, in
particular, implies that this approach has the ability to very
effectively and reliably identify the most relevant features
contained in the data. Specifically, this project leads to
advanced techniques for edge detection, feature extraction, and
texture retrieval from medical, industrial and satellite imagery.
This results in innovative and improved computational algorithms
for the analysis and processing of high-dimensional data and
facilitates technological advances in sensitive applications such
as remote sensing, medical diagnostics, data classification and
electronic surveillance.

Report on award: “Collaborative research: Analysis and processing of multidimensional data using sparse directional multiscale representations”

Processing complex and large-size data generated from a variety of applications ranging from biomedical imaging thorough remote sensing and scientific computing is one of the great challenges of our times. The difficulty comes not only from the amount of data to be processed but also from their complexity. Consider, for example, the complex streams of data collected from hyperspectral airborne cameras or the high-resolution fluorescent imaging data collected in high-content screening applications for drug discovery. There is a compelling need to develop more sensitive and powerful conceptual tools to capture the truly informative features of these types of data.

Mathematical methods from harmonic analysis have traditionally offered an array of tools to deal with problems from signal and image processing. The basic idea at the core of these methods is that signals and images can be broken up into elementary building blocks. Through this decomposition, it is often possible better understand the structure of the data and to cleverly manipulate or process such data by acting on the
decomposition coefficients. Multiscale decompositions and wavelets, in particular, have been remarkably successful in this task during the last two decades. This approach is inspired in part by neurophysiological models of the human early visual processing system (cf. the work of D. Marr). Through a collection of dedicated receptors that are sensitive to scales and locations, the human brain is able to extract the fundamental components of a scene, including edges, and generate a “primal sketch” of the scene.
Similarly, the mathematical theory of wavelets assumes that a general signal or image can be represented as a superposition of waveforms defined at various scales and locations (think of wave-like oscillations with amplitudes that begin at certain locations, increase, and then decrease back to zero). Thanks to the ability to provide efficient representations for a large class of practical signals and fast algorithmic implementations, wavelets have been especially successful in application including
denoising and image compression (the current standard for image compression, JPEG2000, is wavelet-based).

However, while wavelets are optimal in dealing one-dimensional signals, they are often inadequate to deal with data from multidimensional problems since they are not very efficient to capture intrinsic geometrical features of multidimensional phenomena. In recent years, directional multiscale methods such as the shearlet representation have
emerged as most effective alternatives to the conventional wavelet framework. The shearlet representation, whose main theoretical framework was developed by professor Demetrio Labate and the PI, encompasses the mathematical theory of affine systems and, to
date, is the only method able to combine optimal sparsity (few coefficients to compute), efficient transforms (fast computation) and full mathematical justification (great flexibility and versatility).

The goal of this project was to further develop the theoretical foundation of the shearlet framework with the aim to apply these theoretical results to important problems from image processing and data analysis.

The research program conducted under this award had a broad spectrum, bringing advanced and innovative mathematical ideas from harmonic analysis and approximation theory to the solution of challenging problems from data analysis, with particular emphasis on imaging data from biomedical applications.
